>>40767802You can interpret them in either a positive or a negative light, and that choice shapes your relationship with their source. For instance, the text in your picture offsets the words to create the appearance of depth, which is an effect I was playing with in MSPaint quite recently (although in my case it was white on black). I could interpret this as something malicious trying to signal to me that it's watching everything I do in order to disquiet or distract me, or as something benevolent offering me quiet encouragement on my arts and crafts project. From your perspective, the choice of using that text effect will have seemed quite mundane, but I put it to you that your action was somehow selected for in order to create this synchronicity for me, in a way that (I think minimally, which is why subtext and layering is a common device) interferes with your agency as a person. That synchronicities are personal I take as evidence that the source is conscious and deliberate, but given the subjective nature of those two distinctions it's difficult to say with certainty. I would even be tempted to say it's superconscious, in a way that makes our own consciousness appear artificial. As a fun exercise, I encourage you to examine your interactions with other people and ask: Does what I'm saying or doing have a possible subtext that I didn't intend on? Given the person I'm interacting with, is it plausible something else intended for that subtext to exist?
